repo.description: The most widely used Python to C compiler
repo.name: cython

body:
Continuing to Pythonize Ð¡ython documentation!

This PR Pythonizes [this](https://cython.readthedocs.io/en/latest/src/tutorial/pxd_files.html) documentation page.

Lots of process details and standardization are found here: #4187

comment_data.body: I'd prefer inlining these < 10 line examples to having a ton of tiny, separate files. (I could be convinced otherwise if we're separating them out to facilitate testing.)
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -1,48 +1,81 @@
 .. _pxd_files:
 
+*********
 pxd files
-=========
+*********
 
-In addition to the ``.pyx`` source files, Cython uses ``.pxd`` files
+.. include::
+    ../two-syntax-variants-used
+
+In addition to the ``.pyx`` and ``.py`` source files, Cython uses ``.pxd`` files
 which work like C header files -- they contain Cython declarations
 (and sometimes code sections) which are only meant for inclusion by
-Cython modules.  A ``pxd`` file is imported into a ``pyx`` module by
+Cython modules.  A ``.pxd`` file is imported into a ``.pyx`` module by
 using the ``cimport`` keyword.
 
-``pxd`` files have many use-cases:
+``.pxd`` files have many use-cases:
 
 1.  They can be used for sharing external C declarations.
 2.  They can contain functions which are well suited for inlining by
-    the C compiler. Such functions should be marked ``inline``, example::
+    the C compiler. Such functions should be marked ``inline``, example:
+
+    .. tabs::
+
+        .. group-tab:: Pure Python
+
+            .. literalinclude:: ../../examples/tutorial/pxd_files/inline.py

comment_data.body: well, i moved this to the file for this code to be tested

comment_data.body:
This seems borderline misleading. The inline function should really be in a `.pxd` file. It's in a `.pyx` file instead to make it testable. But having an additional `.py` file? I'm not even sure if it works to use `@cython.inline` with a `def` function in a `.pxd` file. And it's definitely not tested by this setup.

How would a reasonable setup look here? Should users have their code duplicated in a `.py` file (to support Python execution and code checkers) and in a `.pxd` file (to allow inlining it in Cython)?
comment_data.diff_hunk:

comment_data.body:
`integrate` certainly isn't the right name for these files.
And they don't feel relevant enough to be in files at all. There's not much to test about them.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -1,48 +1,81 @@
 .. _pxd_files:
 
+*********
 pxd files
-=========
+*********
 
-In addition to the ``.pyx`` source files, Cython uses ``.pxd`` files
+.. include::
+    ../two-syntax-variants-used
+
+In addition to the ``.pyx`` and ``.py`` source files, Cython uses ``.pxd`` files
 which work like C header files -- they contain Cython declarations
 (and sometimes code sections) which are only meant for inclusion by
-Cython modules.  A ``pxd`` file is imported into a ``pyx`` module by
+Cython modules.  A ``.pxd`` file is imported into a ``.pyx`` module by
 using the ``cimport`` keyword.
 
-``pxd`` files have many use-cases:
+``.pxd`` files have many use-cases:
 
 1.  They can be used for sharing external C declarations.
 2.  They can contain functions which are well suited for inlining by
-    the C compiler. Such functions should be marked ``inline``, example::
+    the C compiler. Such functions should be marked ``inline``, example:
+
+    .. tabs::
+
+        .. group-tab:: Pure Python
+
+            .. literalinclude:: ../../examples/tutorial/pxd_files/inline.py
+
+        .. group-tab:: Cython
 
-       cdef inline int int_min(int a, int b):
-           return b if b < a else a
+            .. literalinclude:: ../../examples/tutorial/pxd_files/inline.pyx
 
-3.  When accompanying an equally named ``pyx`` file, they
+3.  When accompanying an equally named ``.pyx`` / ``.py`` file, they
     provide a Cython interface to the Cython module so that other
     Cython modules can communicate with it using a more efficient
     protocol than the Python one.
 
-In our integration example, we might break it up into ``pxd`` files like this:
+In our integration example, we might break it up into ``.pxd`` files like this:
+
+1.  Add a ``cmath.pxd``:
+
+    .. literalinclude:: ../../examples/tutorial/pxd_files/cmath.pxd
+        :caption: cmath.pxd
+
+    Then one would simply do
+
+    .. tabs::
+
+        .. group-tab:: Pure Python
+
+            .. literalinclude:: ../../examples/tutorial/pxd_files/integrate.py
+                :caption: integrate.py
+
+            .. include::
+                ../cimport-warning
+
+        .. group-tab:: Cython
+
+            .. literalinclude:: ../../examples/tutorial/pxd_files/integrate.pyx
+                :caption: integrate.pyx

comment_data.body:
Well, to be honest, I didn't come up with it, it was there, I just adapted it. If you look [here](https://github.com/cython/cython/pull/4295/files#diff-3c94f63d823eb89992e39817d55f31450fc8a119789a3415c989fe19eedf6e21L30):
> Then one would simply do ``from cmath cimport sin`` in ``integrate.pyx``.

you can see that this code is referred to as being in a file.

Of course, we can redo all of this in a better way.

comment_data.body:
> This seems borderline misleading. The inline function should really be in a `.pxd` file.

Oh, I'm sorry, I, apparently, did not read the text well enough. ð

> I'm not even sure if it works to use `@cython.inline` with a `def` function in a `.pxd` file.

Hmm, I will need to test everything with pxd.

> It's in a `.pyx` file instead to make it testable.

If I put them in pxd, will the compilation be checked anyway? As far as I know, the files in the documentation won't run anyway, so we can probably change the file extension to pxd.

> and in a `.pxd` file (to allow inlining it in Cython)?

Cython doesn't support inlining for py?

> Should users have their code duplicated in a `.py` file (to support Python execution and code checkers)

Well, duplication is definitely not welcome.

> How would a reasonable setup look here?

What? I don't really understand your question.

+            .. literalinclude:: ../../examples/tutorial/pxd_files/inline.py

comment_data.body:
> `integrate` certainly isn't the right name for these files.

How should we name them then?

commit.message: add inline.py and inline.pyx to examples
add integrate.py and integrate.pyx to examples
add cmath.pxd and integrate.pxd to examples
pxd_files: add `.py` where needed + add missed dots
pxd_files: add tabs and cimport warnings
pxd_files: use code instead of words

repo.description: The most widely used Python to C compiler
repo.name: cython

title: Pythonise docs: "pxd files" (pxd_files.rst)
